options.text: GMS R59 Early onset or syndromic epilepsy

assignments: indicator.heading='Meets the criteria for Familial hypercholesterolemia'

considerations_text.text='Patients with any of the following should be excluded from recruitment:

* Secondary causes of elevated LDL-C
* Recessive inheritance
* Triglyceride level of over 2.5mmol/l
* Molecular diagnosis based on prior genetic testing

Testing notes:
* Individuals with severe or syndromic disease should be recruited according to standard guidance, typically as trios. Disease status of apparently unaffected participants should be determined according to standard clinical practice to detect cryptic disease.
* In other cases, unaffected individuals should not be recruited. Recruitment in such families should favour multiplex families over single isolated cases. These singleton recruits will not contribute to the overall singleton monitoring metrics applied to GMCs.

Test for the following genes:

* **LDLR, APOB and PCSK9**
* **Polygenic risk 12-SNP gene score**'
actions.name: FH eligibility true

actions.condition: T0_problem_diagnosis_name=='at0080'&&T0_assessment=='Meets the criteria for Rare multisystem ciliopathy disorders'
assignments: indicator.heading='Meets the criteria Rare multisystem ciliopathy disorders'

considerations_text.text='Patients with any of the following should be excluded from recruitment:

* Known genetic cause
* Specific diagnosis of Bardet-Biedl syndrome or other ciliopathy with specific recruitment criteria within the 100,000 Genomes project

Test for the following genes:

* **OFD1**'
actions.name: RMCD eligibility true

assignments: indicator.heading='Insufficient criteria for Rare multisystem ciliopathy disorders'
considerations_text.text='Perform the following clinical tests:\n\n* **General Imaging Diagnostics**'
actions.condition: T0_problem_diagnosis_name=='at0080'&&T0_assessment!='Meets the criteria for Rare multisystem ciliopathy disorders'
actions.name: RMCD eligibility false

actions.condition: T0_problem_diagnosis_name=='at0082'&&T0_assessment=='Meets the criteria for GMS R104 Skeletal dysplasia'
assignments: indicator.heading='Meets the criteria for GMS R104 Skeletal dysplasia'

considerations_text.text='Testing notes:

* Optimal famility structure: Trio.
* Criteria are present at the time of review of clinical features and x-rays by a Clinical Geneticists or Radiologist expert in skeletal dysplasias.
* Molecular diagnosis will guide management or alter advice.'
actions.name: GMS R104 eligibility true

actions.condition: T0_problem_diagnosis_name=='at0082'&&T0_assessment!='Meets the criteria for GMS R104 Skeletal dysplasia'
assignments: indicator.heading='Insufficient criteria for GMS R104 Skeletal dysplasia'
actions.name: GMS R104 eligibility false

actions.condition: T0_problem_diagnosis_name=='at0083'&&T0_assessment=='Meets the criteria for GMS R59 Early onset or syndromic epilepsy'
assignments: indicator.heading='Meets the criteria for GMS R59 Early onset or syndromic epilepsy'

considerations_text.text= 'Testing notes:

* Optimal family structure: Trio.
* Criteria are present at the time of presentation.
* Molecular diagnosis will guide management or alter advice.'
actions.name: GMS R59 eligibility true

actions.condition: T0_problem_diagnosis_name=='at0083'&&T0_assessment!='Meets the criteria for GMS R59 Early onset or syndromic epilepsy'
assignments: indicator.heading='Insufficient criteria for GMS R104 Skeletal dysplasia'
actions.name: GMS R59 eligibility false

assignments: indicator.heading='Meets the criteria for GMS R59 Early onset or syndromic epilepsy'

considerations_text.text='Patients with any of the following should be excluded from recruitment:

* Low birth weight for gestation

Test for the following genes:

* **PTPN11**
* **RAF1**
* **BRAF**
* **SOS1**
* **KRAS**
* **HRAS**
* **NRAS**
* **SHOC2**
* **CBL**
* **SPRED1**
* **MAP2K1**
* **MAP2K2**'
actions.name: Noonan eligibility true

assignments: indicator.heading='Insufficient criteria for GMS R104 Skeletal dysplasia'

considerations_text.text='Perform the following clinical tests:

* **Intelligence Quotient Assessment**
* **Additional body measurements**
* **General Imaging Diagnostics**'
actions.name: Noonan eligibility false

[name='T0_phenotype_identifier_10'].label: Delayed speech and language development code

[name='T0_phenotype_present_13'].label: Microcephaly
[name='T0_phenotype_present_13'].information: Occipito-frontal (head) circumference (OFC) less than -3 standard deviations compared to appropriate, age matched, normal standards (Ross JJ, Frias JL 1977, PMID:9683597). Alternatively, decreased size of the cranium. Comment: Head circumference is measured from just above the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose) to the most posterior prominent point of the occipital bone using a tape measure. Some standard charts are organized by centiles [Hall et al. [2007]], others by standard deviations [Farkas, [1981]]. It is important to add an indication of how far below the normal standard the head circumference is if an accurate assessment of this can be made. Microcephaly is an absolute term. The term relative microcephaly can be used when the head size centile is less than the centile for height, for example, head size at the 3rd centile with height at the 75% for age and sex. On prenatal ultrasound, microcephaly is diagnosed if the head circumference or the biparietal diameter is more than three standard deviations below the mean.

[name='T0_phenotype_present_14'].label: Macrocephaly
[name='T0_phenotype_present_14'].information: Occipitofrontal (head) circumference greater than 97th centile compared to appropriate, age matched, sex-matched normal standards. Alternatively, a apparently increased size of the cranium. Comment: Macrocephaly can be due to hydrocephalus (increased CFSF), megalencephaly (increased brain volume) or thickening of the skull. Head circumference is measured from just above the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose) to the most posterior prominent point of the occipital bone using a tape measure. Some standard charts are organized by centiles [Hall et al. [2007]], others by standard deviations [Farkas, [1981]]. It is important to add an indication of how far above the normal standard the head circumference is if an accurate assessment of this can be made. Macrocephaly is an absolute term. The term relative macrocephaly can be used when the head size centile exceeds the centile for height, for example, head size at the 75th centile with height at the 5th centile for age and sex

[name='T0_phenotype_identifier_72'].label: Delayed speech and language development code

[name='T0_phenotype_identifier_87'].label: Abnormality of the coagulation cascade code

[name='T0_phenotype_description_87'].label: Abnormality of the coagulation cascade text

[name='T0_total_cholesterol_6_7_mmol'].label: Total cholesterol > 6.7 mmol/l (260 mg/dl) in a child < 16 years

[name='T0_ldl_cholesterol_above_4_0'].label: LDL cholesterol above 4.0 mmol/l in a child < 16 years

[name='T0_total_cholesterol_7_5_mmol_l'].label: Total cholesterol >7.5 mmol/l (290 mg/dl) in an adult

[name='T0_ldl_cholesterol_above_4_9'].label: LDL cholesterol above 4.9 mmol/l (190 mg/dl) in an adult

[name='T0_tendon_xanthomas_tx_in_1st'].label: Tendon xanthomas (TX) in 1st degree relative (parent, sibling, child) or in 2nd degree relative (grandparent, uncle, aunt)

[name='T0_total_cholesterol_8_5_mmol_l'].label: Total cholesterol >8.5 mmol/l in an adult

[name='T0_ldl_cholesterol_above_5_5'].label: LDL cholesterol above 5.5 mmol/l in an adult

[name='T0_family_history_of_myocardial'].label: Family history of myocardial infarction below age of 50 in 2nd degree relative or below age 60 in 1st degree relative

[name='T0_family_history_of_raised'].label: Family history of raised cholesterol: >7.5 mmol/l in adult 1st or 2nd degree relative or > 6.7 mmol/l in child or sibling under 16

[name='T0_polygenic_risk_12_snp_gene'].label: Polygenic risk 12-SNP gene score in the bottom two quartiles

[name='T0_clinical_diagnosis_of_a_rare'].label: Clinical diagnosis of a rare multisystem ciliopathy

[name='T0_renal_dysplasia_polycystic'].label: Renal dysplasia, polycystic or bright kidneys

[name='T0_cerebellar_hypoplasia'].label: Cerebellar hypoplasia (especially vermis where visible) / Dandy-Walker malformation or variant

[name='T0_clinical_features_indicative'].label: Clinical features indicative of a likely monogenic skeletal dysplasia

[name='T0_unexplained_epilepsy_with'].label: Unexplained epilepsy with clinical suspicion of a monogenic cause

[name='T0_clinical_features_suggestive'].label: Clinical features suggestive of specific genetic epilepsy, for example Dravet syndrome

[name='T0_early_feeding_difficulty'].label: Early feeding difficulty/ failure to thrive

[name='T0_suggestive_malignancy'].label: Suggestive malignancy ( bladder carcinoma, Rhabdomyosarcoma, Leukaemia, phaeochromocytoma)

[name='T0_skin_abnormalities'].label: Skin abnormalities (hyperkeratosis, cafe au lait patches, ulerythema oophorogenes, keratosis pilaris, excess palmar skin)

#T0_hyperlipidemia.label: Hyperlipidemia
#T0_hyperlipidemia.information: An elevated lipid concentration in the blood. Comment: Hyperlipidemia is an elevation of the blood levels of lipids including primarily cholesterol, phospholipids and triglycerides and cholesterol esters. The lipids are transported on lipoproteins some of which are commonly used for clinical measurements, including chylomicrons, very-low density lipoproteins (VLDL), intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL), low-density lipoproteins, and high-density lipoproteins (HDL).

#T0_hypercholesterolemia.label: Hypercholesterolemia
#T0_hypercholesterolemia.information: An increased concentration of cholesterol in the blood.

#T0_hyperbetalipoproteinemia.label: Hyperbetalipoproteinemia
#T0_hyperbetalipoproteinemia.information: An elevated concentration of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.

#T0_hyperlipoproteinemia.label: Hyperlipoproteinemia
#T0_hyperlipoproteinemia.information: An abnormal increase in the level of lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.

#T0_myocardial_infarction.label: Myocardial infarction
#T0_myocardial_infarction.information: Necrosis of the myocardium caused by an obstruction of the blood supply to the heart and often associated with chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, and anxiety as well as characteristic EKG findings and elevation of serum markers including creatine kinase-MB fraction and troponin.

#T0_hypertriglyceridemia.label: Hypertriglyceridemia
#T0_hypertriglyceridemia.information: An abnormal increase in the level of triglycerides in the blood.

#T0_corneal_arcus.label: Corneal arcus
#T0_corneal_arcus.information: A hazy, grayish-white ring about 2 mm in width located close to but separated from the limbus (the corneoscleral junction). Corneal arcus generally occurs bilaterally, and is related to lipid deposition in the cornea. Corneal arcus can occur in elderly persons as a part of the aging process but may be associated with hypercholesterolemia in people under the age of 50 years. Comment: A grey opaque line which surrounds the margin of the cornea caused by lipid deposits.

#T0_tendon_xanthomatosis.label: Tendon xanthomatosis
#T0_tendon_xanthomatosis.information: The presence of xanthomas (intra-and extra-cellular accumulations of cholesterol) extensor tendons (typically over knuckles, Achilles tendon, knee, and elbows).

[name='T0_comments'].label: Comments
[name='T0_comments'].helpertext: Please do not provide any patient identifying information.

#submit_button.label: Save Assessment To Patient Record
#submit_button.confirmationText:
The following information will be saved to the patient record:

- **selected phenotypes**
- **selected eligibility criteria**
- **eligibility assessment**
- **comments**

#T0_delayed_gross_motor.label: Delayed gross motor development
#T0_delayed_gross_motor.information: A type of motor delay characterized by an delay in acquiring the ability to control the large muscles of the body for walking, running, sitting, and crawling.

#T0_delayed_fine_motor.label: Delayed fine motor development
#T0_delayed_fine_motor.information: A type of motor delay characterized by an delay in acquiring the ability to control the fingers and hands.

#T0_global_developmental_delay.label: Global developmental delay
#T0_global_developmental_delay.information: A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age. Comment: Developmental retardation is any significant lag in development in the any or all of the physical, cognitive, behavioral, emotional, or social spheres. Note that the term intellectual disability (mental retardation) refers to not merely a delay in development but rather a permanent limitation. Note that the term 'psychomotor retardation' is also used in some contexts to refer to a slowing of thought and physical movements as a result of major depression or intoxication.

#T0_intellectual_disability_rmcd.label: Intellectual disability
#T0_intellectual_disability_rmcd.information: Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, has been defined as an IQ score below 70. Comment: This term should be used for children at least five years old. For younger children, consider the term Global developmental delay (HP:0001263).

#T0_microcephaly.label: Delayed speech and language development text

#T0_generalized_hypotonia.label: Generalized hypotonia
#T0_generalized_hypotonia.information: Generalized muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone).

#T0_ataxia.label: Ataxia
#T0_ataxia.information: Cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum. This causes a variety of elementary neurological deficits including asynergy (lack of coordination between muscles, limbs and joints), dysmetria (lack of ability to judge distances that can lead to under- oder overshoot in grasping movements), and dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid movements requiring antagonizing muscle groups to be switched on and off repeatedly). Comment: Ataxia can be differentiated into dyssynergy, asynergy, dysmetria (hypometria, hypermetria), dysdiadochokinesis, gait ataxia, truncal ataxia, limb ataxia, and dysarthria). Note: This term does not include sensory ataxia.

#T0_molar_tooth_sign_on_mri.label: Molar tooth sign on MRI
#T0_molar_tooth_sign_on_mri.information: An abnormal appearance of the midbrain in axial magnetic resonance imaging in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles give the midbrain an appearance reminiscent of a molar or wisdom tooth. Comment: Molar tooth appearance results from a lack of normal decussation of superior cerebellar peduncular fiber tracts which in turn leads to enlargement of the peduncles, which also follow a more horizontal course. The absence of crossing fibers also leads to a reduction in the anteroposterior diameter of the midbrain and deepening of the interpeduncular cistern.

#T0_cerebellar_vermis_hypoplasia.label: Cerebellar vermis hypoplasia
#T0_cerebellar_vermis_hypoplasia.information: Underdevelopment of the vermis of cerebellum.

#T0_occipital_encephalocele_rmcd.label: Occipital encephalocele
#T0_occipital_encephalocele_rmcd.information: A type of encephalocele (that is, a a protrusion of part of the cranial contents including brain tissue through a congenital opening in the cranium, typically covered with skin or mucous membrane) in the occipital region of the skull. Occipital encephalocele presents as a midline swelling over the occipital bone. It is usually covered with normal full-thickness scalp.

#T0_polymicrogyria.label: Polymicrogyria
#T0_polymicrogyria.information: A congenital abnormality of the cerebral hemisphere characterized by an excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of the brain. Comment: Polymicrogyria, one of the most common malformations of cortical development, is characterized histologically by the appearance of an excessive number of small cortical folds, often fused together, with disordered cortical lamination.

#T0_oculomotor_apraxia.label: Oculomotor apraxia
#T0_oculomotor_apraxia.information: Ocular motor apraxia is a deficiency in voluntary, horizontal, lateral, fast eye movements (saccades) with retention of slow pursuit movements. The inability to follow objects visually is often compensated by head movements. There may be decreased smooth pursuit, and cancellation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Comment: Oculomotor apraxia leads defective or absent horizontal voluntary eye movements with head thrusting to look at objects to the side as well as jerky, abnormal eye movements.

#T0_coloboma.label: Coloboma
#T0_coloboma.information: A developmental defect characterized by a cleft of some portion of the eye or ocular adnexa.

#T0_abnormal_facial_shape.label: Abnormal facial shape
#T0_abnormal_facial_shape.information: An abnormal morphology (form) of the face or its components. Comment: This term now covers many of the historical inexact descriptions such as Bird-like facies that probably should be avoided in modern genetics. This portion of the Ontology should be revised.

#T0_accessory_oral_frenulum.label: Accessory oral frenulum
#T0_accessory_oral_frenulum.information: Extra fold of tissue extending from the alveolar ridge to the inner surface of the upper or lower lip. Comment: This finding is assessed by gently retracting the oral mucosa from the alveolar ridge. Typically there is a single maxillary and a single mandibular frenulum located in the midline between the two central incisors. Abnormalities of the alveolar ridges may accompany accessory frenula, but these should be assessed separately.

#T0_cleft_palate.label: Cleft palate
#T0_cleft_palate.information: Cleft palate is a developmental defect of the palate resulting from a failure of fusion of the palatine processes and manifesting as a separation of the roof of the mouth (soft and hard palate). Comment: Cleft palate is a developmental defect that occurs between the 7th and 12th week of pregnancy. Normally, the palatine processes fuse during this time to form the soft and hard palate. A failure of fusion results in a cleft palate. The clinical spectrum ranges from bifid uvula, to (incomplete or complete) cleft of the soft palate, up to (complete or incomplete) cleft of both the soft and hard palate.

#T0_abnormality_of_cardiovascular.label: Abnormality of cardiovascular system morphology
#T0_abnormality_of_cardiovascular.information: Any structural anomaly of the heart and great vessels.

#T0_hyperechogenic_kidneys.label: Hyperechogenic kidneys
#T0_hyperechogenic_kidneys.information: An increase in amplitude of waves returned in ultrasonography of the kidney, which is generally displayed as increased brightness of the signal.

#T0_multiple_renal_cysts.label: Multiple renal cysts
#T0_multiple_renal_cysts.information: The presence of many cysts in the kidney.

#T0_hypertension.label: Hypertension
#T0_hypertension.information: The presence of chronic increased pressure in the systemic arterial system. Comment: Hypertension is sustained elevation of resting systolic BP (140 mm Hg or higher), diastolic BP (90 mm Hg or higher), or both.

#T0_chronic_kidney_disease.label: Chronic kidney disease
#T0_chronic_kidney_disease.information: Functional anomaly of the kidney persisting for at least three months.

#T0_hepatic_fibrosis.label: Hepatic fibrosis
#T0_hepatic_fibrosis.information: The presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in the liver. Fibrosis is a reparative or reactive process.

#T0_elevated_hepatic.label: Elevated hepatic transaminases
#T0_elevated_hepatic.information: Elevations of the levels of SGOT and SGPT in the serum. SGOT (serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase) and SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase) are transaminases primarily found in the liver and heart and are released into the bloodstream as the result of liver or heart damage. SGOT and SGPT are used clinically mainly as markers of liver damage. Comment: previous def: 'has part' some ('increased amount' and ('inheres in' some (IMR\_0000951 and ('part of' some blood))) and ('has modifier' some abnormal))

#T0_preaxial_hand_polydactyly.label: Preaxial hand polydactyly
#T0_preaxial_hand_polydactyly.information: Supernumerary digits located at the radial side of the hand. Polydactyly (supernumerary digits) involving the thumb occurs in many distinct forms of high variability and severity. Ranging from fleshy nubbins over varying degrees of partial duplication/splitting to completely duplicated or even triplicated thumbs or preaxial (on the radial side of the hand) supernumerary digits.

#T0_postaxial_hand_polydactyly.label: Postaxial hand polydactyly
#T0_postaxial_hand_polydactyly.information: Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand (that is, on the side with the fifth finger).

#T0_mesoaxial_hand_polydactyly.label: Mesoaxial hand polydactyly
#T0_mesoaxial_hand_polydactyly.information: The presence of a supernumerary finger (not a thumb) involving the third or fourth metacarpal with associated osseous syndactyly.

#T0_preaxial_foot_polydactyly.label: Preaxial foot polydactyly
#T0_preaxial_foot_polydactyly.information: Duplication of all or part of the first ray. Comment: This term applies for a wide variety of partial and/or complete duplications of the phalanges of the big toe (sometimes including the 1st metatarsal). A partial duplication can present itself on x-rays as a notched phalanx, bifid phalanx or a broadened phalanx. Polydactyly affecting the big toe is called preaxial or hallucal polydactyly of the feet.

#T0_short_stature_rmcd.label: Short stature
#T0_short_stature_rmcd.information: A height below that which is expected according to age and gender norms. Although there is no universally accepted definition of short stature, many refer to "short stature" as height more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender (or below the 3rd percentile for age and gender dependent norms).

#T0_obesity.label: Obesity
#T0_obesity.information: Body weight that is grossly above the acceptable or desirable weight, usually due to accumulation of excess fats in the body. The standards may vary with age, sex, genetic or cultural background. In the body mass index (BMI), a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese, and a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2 is considered morbidly obese.

#T0_postaxial_foot_polydactyly.label: Postaxial foot polydactyly
#T0_postaxial_foot_polydactyly.information: Polydactyly of the foot most commonly refers to the presence of six toes on one foot. Postaxial polydactyly affects the lateral ray and the duplication may range from a well-formed articulated digit to a rudimentary digit. Comment: The modifier postaxial means that the supernumerary digit is not a hallux.

#T0_mesoaxial_foot_polydactyly.label: Mesoaxial foot polydactyly
#T0_mesoaxial_foot_polydactyly.information: The presence of a supernumerary toe (not a hallux) involving the third or fourth metatarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.

#T0_hamartoma_of_tongue.label: Hamartoma of tongue
#T0_hamartoma_of_tongue.information: A benign (noncancerous) tumorlike malformation made up of an abnormal mixture of cells and tissues that originates in the tongue.

#T0_skeletal_dysplasia.label: Skeletal dysplasia
#T0_skeletal_dysplasia.information: A general term describing features characterized by abnormal development of bones and connective tissues. Comment: The word skeletal dysplasia is most often used to describe a group of over 380 inherited conditions that involve abnormal development of bones and connective tissues. However, the word can also be used to describe the presence of a congenital defects of bones or connective tissues that are found in one or more of the diseases, especially on prenatal ultrasound, i.e., a situation in which it is often not yet possible to make an exact etiological diagnosis. This is the sense of the phrase we use in the HPO. It is, however, preferable to annotate the observed abnormalities.

#T0_short_stature_1.label: Short stature
#T0_short_stature_1.information: A height below that which is expected according to age and gender norms. Although there is no universally accepted definition of short stature, many refer to "short stature" as height more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender (or below the 3rd percentile for age and gender dependent norms).

#T0_intellectual_disability_2.label: Intellectual disability
#T0_intellectual_disability_2.information: Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, has been defined as an IQ score below 70. Comment: This term should be used for children at least five years old. For younger children, consider the term Global developmental delay (HP:0001263).

#T0_abnormal_facial_shape_1.label: Abnormal facial shape
#T0_abnormal_facial_shape_1.information: An abnormal morphology (form) of the face or its components. Comment: This term now covers many of the historical inexact descriptions such as Bird-like facies that probably should be avoided in modern genetics. This portion of the Ontology should be revised.

#T0_global_developmental_delay_1.label: Global developmental delay
#T0_global_developmental_delay_1.information: A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age. Comment: Developmental retardation is any significant lag in development in the any or all of the physical, cognitive, behavioral, emotional, or social spheres. Note that the term intellectual disability (mental retardation) refers to not merely a delay in development but rather a permanent limitation. Note that the term 'psychomotor retardation' is also used in some contexts to refer to a slowing of thought and physical movements as a result of major depression or intoxication.

#T0_generalized_seizures.label: Generalized seizures
#T0_generalized_seizures.information: Seizures of with initial involvement of both cerebral hemispheres. Comment: Generalized seizures are sub-categorized into several major types: generalized tonic clonic; myoclonic; absence; and atonic.

#T0_focal_seizures.label: Focal seizures
#T0_focal_seizures.information: Seizures of which initial semiology indicates, or is consistent with, initial activation of only part of one cerebral hemisphere. Comment: Partial seizures can be classified as simple (consciousness is maintained) or complex (consciousness is impaired or lost).

#T0_epileptic_spasms.label: Epileptic spasms
#T0_epileptic_spasms.information: A sudden flexion, extension or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles which is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure. Comment: The maximum age of onset is between 3 and 12 months, the peak being at 6 months. However, spasms may start from birth, or appear long after the age of 12 months, including into adulthood. Infantile spasms represent a specific type of seizure seen in an epilepsy syndrome of infancy and childhood known as West Syndrome. West Syndrome is characterized by infantile spasms, developmental regression, and hypsarrhythmia (as demonstrated by electroencephalography).

#T0_infantile_encephalopathy.label: Infantile encephalopathy
#T0_infantile_encephalopathy.information: Encephalopathy with onset in the infantile period.

#T0_intellectual_disability_3.label: Intellectual disability
#T0_intellectual_disability_3.information: Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, has been defined as an IQ score below 70. Comment: This term should be used for children at least five years old. For younger children, consider the term Global developmental delay (HP:0001263).

#T0_abnormal_facial_shape_2.label: Abnormal facial shape
#T0_abnormal_facial_shape_2.information: An abnormal morphology (form) of the face or its components. Comment: This term now covers many of the historical inexact descriptions such as Bird-like facies that probably should be avoided in modern genetics. This portion of the Ontology should be revised.

#T0_global_developmental_delay_2.label: Global developmental delay
#T0_global_developmental_delay_2.information: A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age. Comment: Developmental retardation is any significant lag in development in the any or all of the physical, cognitive, behavioral, emotional, or social spheres. Note that the term intellectual disability (mental retardation) refers to not merely a delay in development but rather a permanent limitation. Note that the term 'psychomotor retardation' is also used in some contexts to refer to a slowing of thought and physical movements as a result of major depression or intoxication.

#T0_increased_nuchal_translucency.label: Increased nuchal translucency
#T0_increased_nuchal_translucency.information: The presence of an abnormally large hypoechoic space in the posterior fetal neck (usually detected on prenatal ultrasound examination). Comment: Increased nuchal translucency may be related to a cystic hygroma or to mesenchymal edema. Increased nuchal translucency can be classified into three categories: 1) cardiac abnormalities, combined with abnormal ductus venosus flow velocities, is found, leading to the theory that cardiac failure causes nuchal translucency enlargement; 2) various types of abnormalities are found in the extracellular matrix of the nuchal skin of fetuses with increased nuchal translucency; 3) abnormal lymphatic development is demonstrated in fetuses with increased nuchal translucency.

#T0_polyhydramnios.label: Polyhydramnios
#T0_polyhydramnios.information: The presence of excess amniotic fluid in the uterus during pregnancy. Comment: Polyhydramnios is diagnosed if the deepest vertical pool of amniotic fluid is more than 8 cm or amniotic fluid index is more than 95th percentile for the corresponding gestational age.

#T0_feeding_difficulties.label: Feeding difficulties
#T0_feeding_difficulties.information: Impaired ability to eat related to problems gathering food and getting ready to suck, chew, or swallow it.

#T0_pulmonic_stenosis.label: Pulmonic stenosis
#T0_pulmonic_stenosis.information: A narrowing of the right ventricular outflow tract that can occur at the pulmonary valve (valvular stenosis) or just below the pulmonary valve (infundibular stenosis). Comment: Infundibular pulmonic stenosis is mostly caused by overgrowth of the heart muscle wall (hypertrophy of the septoparietal trabeculae). Pulmonic stenosis is often seen as a part of Fallot' s tetralogy, in which case the events leading to the formation of the overriding aorta are also believed to be a cause of the pulmonic stenosis. The pulmonic stenosis is the major cause of the malformations seen in patients with Fallot tetralogy, with the other associated malformations acting as compensatory mechanisms to the pulmonic stenosis. The degree of stenosis varies between individuals with TOF, and is the primary determinant of symptoms and severity. This malformation is infrequently described as sub-pulmonary stenosis or subpulmonary obstruction.

#T0_hypertrophic_cardiomyopathy.label: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
#T0_hypertrophic_cardiomyopathy.information: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is defined by the presence of increased ventricular wall thickness or mass in the absence of loading conditions (hypertension, valve disease) sufficient to cause the observed abnormality.

#T0_abnormality_of_the.label: Abnormality of the atrioventricular valves
#T0_abnormality_of_the.information: An abnormality of an atrioventricular valve.

#T0_atrial_septal_defect.label: Atrial septal defect
#T0_atrial_septal_defect.information: Atrial septal defect (ASD) is a congenital abnormality of the interatrial septum that enables blood flow between the left and right atria via the interatrial septum.

#T0_ventricular_septal_defect.label: Ventricular septal defect
#T0_ventricular_septal_defect.information: A hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart. The defect is centered around the most superior aspect of the ventricular septum.

#T0_arrhythmia_ns.label: Arrhythmia
#T0_arrhythmia_ns.information: Any cardiac rhythm other than the normal sinus rhythm. Such a rhythm may be either of sinus or ectopic origin and either regular or irregular. An arrhythmia may be due to a disturbance in impulse formation or conduction or both.

#T0_lymphedema.label: Lymphedema
#T0_lymphedema.information: Localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system.

#T0_pleural_effusion.label: Pleural effusion
#T0_pleural_effusion.information: The presence of an excessive amount of fluid in the pleural cavity.

#T0_intellectual_disability_1.label: Intellectual disability
#T0_intellectual_disability_1.information: Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, has been defined as an IQ score below 70. Comment: This term should be used for children at least five years old. For younger children, consider the term Global developmental delay (HP:0001263).

#T0_nonimmune_hydrops_fetalis.label: Nonimmune hydrops fetalis
#T0_nonimmune_hydrops_fetalis.information: A type of hydrops fetalis in which there is no identifiable circulating antibody to red blood cell antigens .

#T0_delayed_speech_and_language_rmcd.label: Delayed speech and language development
#T0_delayed_speech_and_language_rmcd.information: A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age. Comment: Language delay can be characterized by a failure to meet the developmental milestones for language development, an inability to follow directions, or slow or incomprehensible speech after the age of three years, as well as with severe problems with syntax or articulation.
